Synopsis: Applying to electric cooperatives certain provisions of law related to rate proceedings held by the Public Service Commission to determine whether additional revenues are required to allow certain public service companies to earn the existing fair rate of return authorized in a previous base rate proceeding; and requiring the Commission to order an electric cooperative to conduct a certain public hearing.
bill_summary: This bill applies certain rate proceeding rules to electric cooperatives in Maryland, requiring the Public Service Commission to hold public hearings and determine if additional revenues are needed for cooperatives to earn their authorized rates, with provisions for public notice and potential rate adjustments.
responsible_party: Public Service Commission of Maryland
stakeholders: Electric cooperatives and their customers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs existing regulatory processes with added requirements for public hearings and transparency, but does not introduce new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on utility rate regulation.

Title: Baltimore County - Alcoholic Beverages - Class B-OB-CRD (Office Building - Commercial Revitalization District) Beer, Wine, and Liquor License
Synopsis: Establishing a Class B-OB-CRD (office building - commercial revitalization district) beer, wine, and liquor license in Baltimore County; authorizing the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County to issue the license to an establishment that previously had or has a certain zoning classification and is at least a certain distance from a place of worship under certain circumstances and subject to certain limitations; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a new Class B–OB–CRD (office building – commercial revitalization district) beer, wine, and liquor license in Baltimore County, allowing certain restaurants in specific districts to sell alcohol under particular conditions, including proximity to places of worship.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of License Commissioners
stakeholders: Restaurants and establishments in Baltimore County, particularly in the Towson commercial revitalization district and office buildings of at least 100,000 square feet
innovative_summary: The program introduces a specialized license for restaurants in office buildings within a designated district, with specific proximity and zoning requirements, representing a targeted approach to alcohol licensing.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on licensing rules for alcohol sales.

Title: Montgomery County - Speed Monitoring Systems - Maryland Route 200 (Intercounty Connector) MC 10-25
Synopsis: Authorizing the placement and use by the Maryland Transportation Authority of speed monitoring systems on Maryland Route 200 (Intercounty Connector) in Montgomery County; requiring the District Court to remit to the Authority any civil penalties collected by the District Court resulting from a citation issued using a speed monitoring system operated by the Authority; and requiring the State Highway Administration to provide the Authority with access to certain systems and contacts.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Transportation Authority to place and use speed monitoring systems on Maryland Route 200 (Intercounty Connector) in Montgomery County, and establishes procedures for collecting and remitting civil penalties from traffic citations issued using these systems.
responsible_party: Maryland Transportation Authority
stakeholders: Drivers and residents in Montgomery County, Maryland, especially those on Maryland Route 200
innovative_summary: The program employs automated speed monitoring systems controlled by the Maryland Transportation Authority, with detailed oversight, calibration, and reporting requirements, representing a technologically advanced approach to traffic enforcement.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily focuses on traffic enforcement and revenue collection.

Title: State Procurement - Minority Business Enterprise Program - Extension and Reports
Synopsis: Altering the termination date for certain provisions of law governing the Minority Business Enterprise Program and its application to public-private partnerships, offshore wind projects, video lottery terminals, and sports wagering licenses; and altering the date by which certain reports, studies, and guidelines must be submitted.
bill_summary: The bill extends the termination dates of various minority business enterprise programs and related regulations in Maryland, delaying their expiration from 2025 to 2026, and requires new reports and analyses on program compliance and effectiveness.
responsible_party: Maryland State agencies involved in minority business enterprise programs, including the Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs and the Board of Public Works.
stakeholders: Minority-owned businesses, state government agencies, and entities involved in public-private partnerships and offshore wind projects.
innovative_summary: The bill primarily focuses on extending existing programs and conducting analyses; it does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it mainly concerns minority business programs and regulatory extensions.

Title: Workgroup to Study the Rise in Adverse Decisions in the State Health Care System - Establishment
Synopsis: §Establishing the Workgroup to Study the Rise in Adverse Decisions in the State Health Care System to make recommendations to improve State reporting on adverse decisions, reduce the number of adverse decisions, and develop recommendations for legislation to address the rise in adverse decisions; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to certain committees of the General Assembly by December 1, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a Workgroup to Study the Rise in Adverse Decisions in the State Health Care System, tasked with reviewing reporting requirements, making recommendations to improve reporting and reduce adverse decisions, and proposing legislation.
responsible_party: Health Services Cost Review Commission and Maryland Insurance Administration
stakeholders: Health payers, healthcare providers, patients, and advocacy organizations in Maryland
innovative_summary: The program aims to standardize reporting and decision-making processes across health payers, which is a relatively innovative approach to improving transparency and reducing adverse decisions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to improve healthcare decision processes, which could indirectly benefit children by improving access and coverage.

Title: Public Health - Phenibut Consumer Protection Act (JT Alvey Phenibut Consumer Protection Act)
Synopsis: Requiring a retailer that prepares, distributes, sells, or exposes for sale a phenibut product to disclose the factual basis on which any representations regarding the phenibut product are made; establishing prohibitions related to the preparation, distribution, and sale of phenibut products, including prohibitions related to the sale of phenibut to individuals under the age of 21 years and the marketing of phenibut to minors; establishing certain penalties for violations of the Act; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes regulations for the sale and marketing of phenibut products in Maryland, including disclosure requirements, restrictions on sale to minors, and advertising limitations, and mandates a report on adverse health events related to phenibut.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Consumers of phenibut products, retailers, and minors in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive regulatory approach including disclosure, advertising restrictions, and reporting requirements to protect public health from phenibut risks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on health and safety regulations.

Title: Public Health - Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias - Information on Prevalence and Treatment
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health, in partnership with certain entities, to incorporate information regarding treatments approved by the Food and Drug Administration for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias and to increase understanding and awareness of treatment of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias into relevant public health outreach programs; requiring the Department to establish and maintain a website with information on the prevalence and hospitalization rate for Alzheimer's and related dementias;  etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to incorporate information about treatments approved by the FDA for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias into public health outreach programs. It also mandates the creation of a website that provides data on the prevalence and hospitalization rates of Alzheimer's and related dementias, disaggregated by various demographics.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Individuals with or at risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, healthcare providers, and the general public in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill employs a data-driven approach by establishing a publicly accessible website with detailed, disaggregated data on Alzheimer's and related dementias, and integrates information on FDA-approved treatments into public health outreach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has moderate potential to impact child poverty by increasing awareness and early detection of Alzheimer's, which can reduce long-term care costs and improve quality of life.

Title: Disability and Life Insurance - Medical Information (Genetic Testing Protection Act)
Synopsis: Prohibiting insurance carriers that offer life insurance or disability insurance policies or contracts from unfairly discriminating against an individual by taking certain actions relating to coverage based on medical information; prohibiting certain carriers from accessing sensitive medical information without first obtaining written consent or mandating certain genetic testing or full genome sequencing as a prerequisite for life insurance or disability insurance eligibility or coverage;  etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits insurance companies offering life, long-term care, or disability insurance in Maryland from discriminating against individuals based on genetic testing results, without a clear relationship to insurance risk. It also restricts access to genetic information without consent and bans mandatory genetic testing for coverage.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Individuals applying for or holding life, long-term care, or disability insurance in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces protections against genetic discrimination in insurance, aligning with modern privacy and anti-discrimination approaches, but does not employ new technologies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on insurance discrimination protections.

Title: African American Heritage Preservation Program and Grant Fund - Noncapital Grants and Donations
Synopsis: Altering the purpose of the African American Heritage Preservation Program and Grant Fund to provide funding for African American Heritage Preservation Noncapital Grants for the purpose of preserving or sharing African American history or culture in the State; requiring certain noncapital grants to be made using certain money received by the African American Heritage Preservation (AAHP) Grant Fund; and authorizing the AAHP Grant Fund to receive grants and donations.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the African American Heritage Preservation Program and Grant Fund to include funding for noncapital grants aimed at preserving or sharing African American history and culture in Maryland. It establishes a dedicated grant fund with an annual appropriation of 5 million dollars, and sets procedures for applying, awarding, and reporting on grants.
responsible_party: Trust in partnership with the Commission on African American History and Culture
stakeholders: African American communities, historical preservation organizations, local governments, and the general public interested in African American history and culture in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program employs a structured approach to funding and preserving African American history through grants, including emergency grants, with oversight and reporting mechanisms, but does not employ new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by preserving cultural heritage and supporting community development.

Title: Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority Task Force - Revisions
Synopsis: Requiring the Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority Task Force to identify certain funding sources and mechanisms, and to submit a report to the Governor, the Mayor of Baltimore City, and the General Assembly on its findings and recommendations by December 1, 2025; and extending the termination date for the Task Force from June 30, 2025, to June 30, 2026.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority, a new state entity responsible for overseeing the renovation, revitalization, and operation of the Baltimore Convention site and surrounding area, including marketing Baltimore as a tourist destination.
responsible_party: Baltimore Convention and Tourism Redevelopment and Operating Authority
stakeholders: Tourists, Baltimore City residents, local businesses, and the tourism industry in Baltimore
innovative_summary: The program employs a new government authority with broad powers to manage, develop, and finance the Baltimore Convention site and surrounding area, including issuing bonds and entering into contracts.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to impact child poverty indirectly through economic development and tourism growth, but does not directly target child poverty.

Title: Financial Institutions - Conventional Home Mortgage Loans - Assumption and Required Disclosures
Synopsis: Requiring banking institutions, credit unions, mortgage lenders, mortgage lending businesses, and mortgage loan originators to include a certain provision in certain conventional home mortgage loans authorizing a certain borrower to purchase the property interest of a certain borrower in connection with a decree of absolute divorce if the lending entity determines that the assuming borrower qualifies for the loan; applying certain provisions of the Act retroactively; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires certain banking and credit union institutions in Maryland to include provisions in conventional home mortgage loans that allow borrowers to assume the mortgage in connection with a divorce decree, and to disclose this provision to applicants. It also clarifies definitions related to mortgage loans and establishes rules for mortgage lenders and originators.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Financial Institutions
stakeholders: Homeowners, mortgage lenders, credit unions, individuals going through divorce
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a specific legal provision allowing mortgage assumption in divorce cases, with mandatory disclosures, which is a targeted approach to address mortgage transfer issues in divorce proceedings.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it mainly addresses mortgage assumptions in divorce cases.

Title: Consumer Protection - Credit Reporting - Medical Debt (Fair Medical Debt Reporting Act)
Synopsis: Prohibiting a consumer reporting agency from furnishing any consumer report containing certain adverse information relating to a consumer's medical debt, or any collection action against a consumer for medical debt, or maintain a file on a consumer related to medical debt or collections; prohibiting a person from using medical debt information from a consumer report for certain purposes; prohibiting a health care facility, a health care practitioner, or an ambulance service from disclosing medical debt to a consumer reporting agency; etc.
bill_summary: The bill prohibits the inclusion of medical debt information in consumer reports, restricts the use of medical debt in creditworthiness decisions, and sets rules for hospitals and healthcare providers regarding debt collection and reporting.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Consumer Protection Agency
stakeholders: Consumers, patients, healthcare providers, hospitals, and debt collection agencies in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs new legal restrictions on the reporting and use of medical debt, including prohibiting reporting of medical debt to credit agencies and requiring contracts to include specific provisions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by reducing financial burdens related to medical debt for families.

Title: Real Estate Appraisers - Licensure and Certification - Qualifications
Synopsis: Prohibiting the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers, Appraisal Management Companies, and Home Inspectors from requiring an applicant to hold a bachelor's degree or higher to qualify for a certain certification or licensure as a real estate appraiser.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland law to prohibit the State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers from requiring applicants for real estate appraiser licenses or certificates to hold a bachelor's degree or higher, aligning licensing requirements with federal standards.
responsible_party: Maryland State Commission of Real Estate Appraisers
stakeholders: Aspiring real estate appraisers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill simplifies licensing requirements by removing the bachelor's degree requirement, making the process more accessible and aligned with federal standards.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily changes licensing requirements for real estate appraisers.

Title: Frederick County - Alcoholic Beverages - Tasting Permits
Synopsis: Altering in Frederick County the beer and wine consumption permit to be the beer and wine tasting permit and the beer, wine, and liquor consumption permit to be the beer, wine, and liquor tasting permit; and requiring the Board to regulate the quantity of beer and wine served to an individual and the number of bottles or other containers from which the quantity is served.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the alcohol tasting permits in Frederick County, changing the names of the permits, adjusting the allowed quantities of alcohol that can be tasted, and updating the fees for these permits.
responsible_party: Frederick County Alcoholic Beverages Board
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders, consumers in Frederick County, local businesses, and the general public interested in alcohol tasting events.
innovative_summary: The bill updates existing alcohol tasting permits with new names, quantities, and fees, but does not introduce new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily concerns alcohol tasting permits for licensed establishments.

Title: Workgroup to Study Implementation of an Expanded 3-1-1 Nonemergency System
Synopsis: Establishing the Workgroup to Study Implementation of an Expanded 3-1-1 Nonemergency System; requiring the Workgroup to review a certain study completed by the Department of Information Technology in order to establish a plan to implement the recommendations of the study; and requiring the Workgroup to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by November 1, 2025.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a workgroup to study the implementation of an expanded 3-1-1 nonemergency telephone system in Maryland, including reviewing current services, best practices, and developing a plan for expansion.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Information Technology
stakeholders: Maryland residents, public safety agencies, telecommunications industry, local governments
innovative_summary: The bill proposes to develop an expanded virtual 3-1-1 portal and improve nonemergency communication systems, which involves integrating new technology and best practices.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could improve access to nonemergency services, potentially aiding vulnerable populations, but its direct impact on child poverty is indirect.

Title: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System - Investment Division - Compensation and Staffing
Synopsis: Clarifying that the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System shall pay certain incentive compensation to the Chief Investment Officer for the State Retirement and Pension System if the Chief Investment Officer retires from the Investment Division of the State Retirement Agency in a certain manner; clarifying that the Board of Trustees shall pay certain incentive compensation to certain employees of the Investment Division if the employees retire from the Investment Division in a certain manner; etc.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies the compensation, incentives, and staffing procedures for the Board of Trustees of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, including establishing a new Compensation and Staffing Committee and setting rules for incentive payments to the Chief Investment Officer and Investment Division staff.
responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Employees of the Investment Division, Chief Investment Officer, and the Board of Trustees
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a structured approach to compensation and incentives, including objective criteria and oversight committees, but does not employ new technologies or radically new approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on pension system governance and staff compensation.

Title: Correctional Officers' Retirement System - Membership - Clarifications
Synopsis: Clarifying the membership in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System for certain employees of certain Maryland Department of Health facilities; and clarifying that certain participating employees who are appointed, promoted, or transferred are members of the Correctional Officers' Retirement System as a condition of employment.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies membership rules and transfer procedures for employees of certain Maryland Department of Health facilities into the Correctional Officers' Retirement System, including provisions for unused sick leave credit and service transfer options.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Employees of Maryland Department of Health facilities and correctional officers
innovative_summary: The bill employs a structured approach to transfer and crediting of service and sick leave, but does not employ new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty, as it mainly concerns retirement system membership and service credit transfer for employees.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Reemployment Earnings Limitations - Maximum Average Final Compensation
Synopsis: Clarifying that the maximum average final compensation that certain retirees of the State Retirement and Pension System is to be based on the minimum annual salary on the standard State pay scale as of January 1 of the preceding calendar year in order to be exempt from a certain reemployment earnings limitation; and adding an average final compensation reemployment exemption for the temporary suspension of a retirement allowance for disability retirees.
bill_summary: The bill clarifies the calculation of the maximum average final compensation for retirees of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, specifically to exempt certain reemployment earnings from limitations if the retiree's average final compensation was below a specified minimum salary as of January 1 of the previous year. It also introduces an exemption for the temporary suspension of disability retirement allowances.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Retirees of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, especially those reemployed after retirement
innovative_summary: The bill employs a clarifying approach to existing pension rules, with a focus on specific salary thresholds and exemptions, rather than introducing new technologies or innovative methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily addresses pension calculation rules for retirees.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System – Alterations and Clarifications
Synopsis: Altering certain due dates of certain reports from the State Retirement and Pension System; and clarifying the eligibility requirements of State Police Retirement System members to participate in the Deferred Retirement Option Program.
bill_summary: The bill makes changes to the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System, including updating report due dates, clarifying eligibility for the Deferred Retirement Option Program (DROP) for State Police Retirement System members, and other administrative clarifications.
responsible_party: Maryland State Retirement Agency
stakeholders: Members of the Maryland State Police Retirement System and related state pension administrators
innovative_summary: The bill primarily updates rules and clarifies eligibility for existing retirement programs; it does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly address child poverty or include programs aimed at reducing it.

Title: Electricity and Gas - Emissions Reductions, Rate Regulation, Cost Recovery, Infrastructure, Planning, Renewable Energy Portfolio Standard, and Energy Assistance Programs (Next Generation Energy Act)
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of Housing and Community Development to issue loans, in addition to grants, for certain purposes relating to reducing direct greenhouse gas emissions from certain multifamily residential buildings; requiring the Maryland Energy Administration, in coordination with the Public Service Commission and the Department of Natural Resources, to pursue certain agreements with neighboring states and federal agencies related to the development of new nuclear energy generation stations; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes Maryland to issue loans and grants for reducing greenhouse gas emissions from multifamily buildings, pursues agreements for nuclear energy development, expands energy procurement sources, and establishes programs for energy storage, nuclear energy, and energy efficiency, including procurement, regulation, and community benefit agreements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development, Maryland Energy Administration, Public Service Commission, Department of Natural Resources, Maryland Department of Labor, and other state agencies involved in energy and utilities.
stakeholders: Low- to moderate-income households, energy companies, industrial and commercial large load customers, local businesses, minority and women-owned businesses, residents, and environmental groups.
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive and technologically advanced approach, including nuclear energy agreements, energy storage, and expedited permitting processes, integrating new technologies and innovative procurement and regulation methods.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a high potential to impact child poverty by supporting energy affordability and reducing emissions in low-income communities.

Title: Public Utilities - Generating Stations - Generation and Siting (Renewable Energy Certainty Act)
Synopsis: Altering the factors the Public Service Commission must consider before taking final action on a certificate of public convenience and necessity; establishing a distributed generation certificate of public convenience and necessity to authorize the construction and operation of a certain distributed solar energy generating system; requiring the Power Plant Research Program, by July 1, 2026, to develop and submit to the Commission proposed siting and design requirements and licensing conditions; etc.
bill_summary: This bill updates Maryland's regulations on the siting, construction, and approval process for renewable energy generating stations, especially solar energy systems. It establishes new standards for distributed solar projects, streamlines permitting, and promotes community solar programs, including automatic enrollment and low-income participation.
responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission and Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Residents, low-income communities, solar developers, local governments, and environmental groups
innovative_summary: The bill introduces innovative approaches such as standardized siting requirements for distributed solar, automatic enrollment in community solar programs, and streamlined permitting processes, leveraging technology and new regulatory frameworks.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has high potential to reduce child poverty by increasing access to affordable solar energy and community solar programs targeted at low-income households.

Title: Energy Resource Adequacy and Planning Act
Synopsis: Establishing the Strategic Energy Planning Office; requiring the Office to develop a Comprehensive Wholesale Energy Markets and Bulk Power System Risk Report and examine certain scenarios to support the development of the Risk Report; requiring the Risk Report to assess wholesale energy market financial resource adequacy and reliability risks and to identify any necessary cost-effective solutions that ensure electric system reliability while meeting the State's energy policy goals; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Strategic Energy Planning Office within the Maryland Public Service Commission to develop comprehensive energy forecasts, conduct risk assessments of wholesale energy markets, and examine scenarios to support energy planning and policy goals, including greenhouse gas reduction and energy reliability.
responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission and Maryland Energy Administration
stakeholders: Electricity consumers, energy producers, state agencies, and communities affected by energy policies
innovative_summary: The bill employs advanced modeling, stakeholder engagement, and comprehensive scenario analysis to guide long-term energy planning, integrating new technologies and market strategies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has high potential to impact child poverty by promoting affordable, reliable, and clean energy, which can reduce energy costs for families and support economic development.

Title: Health Insurance, Family Planning Services, and Confidentiality of Medical Records - Consumer Protections - Updates
Synopsis: Updating references to federal law related to family planning services, grandfathered plans, explanation of benefits, summaries of benefits and coverage, medical loss ratios, catastrophic plans, annual limits for cost sharing, prescription drugs, and rescissions; altering the definitions of "legally protected health care" and "sensitive health services" to include gender-affirming care for purposes of law governing the disclosure of information regarding sensitive health services; etc.
bill_summary: The bill updates Maryland laws related to health insurance, family planning services, and confidentiality of medical records. It clarifies definitions, aligns state law with federal regulations, and ensures access to family planning and gender-affirming care, especially for providers affected by federal funding changes.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Insurance Commissioner
stakeholders: Individuals seeking family planning, reproductive health, and gender-affirming care in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive update to existing health laws, aligning state regulations with federal standards and expanding protections for sensitive health services, including gender-affirming care.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by improving access to reproductive and family planning services, which can influence economic stability for families.

Title: Mechanical Repair Contracts - Technical Service Bulletins
Synopsis: Prohibiting a mechanical repair contract from containing a provision precluding coverage for service to a motor vehicle solely for issues identified in a technical services bulletin and prohibiting the denial of a service claim solely for such an issue by a guarantor or provider.
bill_summary: This bill establishes rules for mechanical repair contracts for motor vehicles, including prohibiting deceptive statements, ensuring truthful testimonials, and preventing coverage denial based on technical service bulletins. It also introduces requirements for disclosures about warranties and coverage.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Insurance
stakeholders: Consumers purchasing or using mechanical repair contracts for motor vehicles
innovative_summary: The bill employs new regulations to prevent coverage denial based on technical service bulletins and mandates truthful advertising and disclosures, representing a proactive approach to consumer protection in vehicle repair services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty but improves consumer protections in vehicle repair services.

Title: Judicial and Public Safety for Service Members Act
Synopsis: Establishing rules of interpretation related to the uniformed services; altering the rule of interpretation for "veteran"; and altering the application of certain provisions of judicial proceedings, corrections, criminal, family, public safety, and real property laws to apply to all uniformed services, rather than only the armed forces.
bill_summary: This bill, titled the Judicial and Public Safety for Service Members Act, establishes rules of interpretation related to the uniformed services, broadens the application of laws concerning veterans and service members, and makes various legal and procedural adjustments to benefit members of the armed forces, veterans, and their families in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans and Military Families
stakeholders: Members of the military, veterans, their families, and the general public in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive approach to legal and procedural reforms for service members and veterans, including clarifications of legal definitions and protections, but does not introduce new technologies or innovative approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, primarily through legal protections and benefits for military families.

Title: Montgomery County Planning Board and Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission - Open Meetings - Live Streaming Requirement MC/PG 101-25
Synopsis: Establishing that certain project site visits and educational field tours do not constitute open meetings subject to the requirement that the Montgomery County Planning Board and the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission, respectively, stream live video or audio of their open meetings.
bill_summary: The bill establishes that certain project site visits and educational field tours do not count as open meetings requiring live streaming or recording by the Montgomery County Planning Board and the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission, and sets specific rules for live streaming and recording of open meetings.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Planning Board and Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission
stakeholders: Public interested in open meetings and transparency of county and utility agency meetings
innovative_summary: The bill employs technology to increase transparency by requiring live streaming and archiving of open meetings, with specific exemptions for certain site visits and tours.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on transparency of government meetings.

Title: Prince George's County - Board of Appeals - Membership MC/PG 106-25
Synopsis: Altering the membership of the board of appeals in Prince George's County to be at least three members; and altering the number of members of the board required to concur in any resolution to a simple majority.
bill_summary: This bill alters the membership and voting requirements of the Board of Appeals in Prince George's County, including the number of members and the majority needed to concur in resolutions.
responsible_party: Prince George's County Council
stakeholders: Residents and officials involved in land use and appeals in Prince George's County
innovative_summary: The bill mainly updates governance rules for the Board of Appeals, with no new technology or innovative approach introduced.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill does not directly impact child poverty.

Title: Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access - Workgroups
Synopsis: Requiring the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access to establish a workgroup on the improvement of health, social, and economic outcomes related to substance use; requiring the workgroup to make recommendations on changes to State laws, policies and practices needed to mitigate the harm related to criminalization of substance use and related to the discharge of patients from substance use treatment programs; and requiring the workgroup to submit a certain report annually.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a workgroup within the Maryland Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access to focus on improving health, social, and economic outcomes related to substance use, and outlines the composition, responsibilities, and reporting requirements for this workgroup.
responsible_party: Maryland Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access
stakeholders: Individuals with substance use disorders, their families, healthcare providers, criminal justice system, and community organizations in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The bill employs a collaborative, multidisciplinary approach by creating specialized workgroups to evaluate and improve substance use treatment and criminal justice policies, integrating health, social, and economic strategies.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to reduce child poverty by improving access to substance use treatment and related social services, which can stabilize families and improve economic outcomes.

Title: Life and Health Insurance Policies and Annuity and Health Maintenance Organization Contracts - Discretionary Clauses - Prohibition
Synopsis: Prohibiting the use of discretionary clauses in life insurance policies, health insurance policies, annuity contracts, and health maintenance organization contracts.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits the use of discretionary clauses in health insurance policies, life insurance policies, annuity contracts, and health maintenance organization contracts in Maryland, effective from January 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Insurance Administration
stakeholders: Consumers of health and life insurance policies and annuity holders in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a legal restriction on discretionary clauses in insurance contracts, which is a regulatory approach rather than a technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it mainly affects insurance policy language and interpretation.

Title: State Retirement and Pension System - Administrative Fees - Repeal
Synopsis: Requiring the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System to certify certain employer contribution rates each fiscal year; requiring the employer contribution rates to include recognition of certain administrative and operational expenses; repealing a requirement that certain administrative and operational expenses of the State Retirement and Pension System and the State Retirement Agency be funded by charging each participating employer an administrative fee for each system participant; etc.
bill_summary: The bill repeals the requirement that administrative and operational expenses of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System be funded through employer administrative fees, and instead funds these expenses through the system's accumulation fund, with future inclusion in employer contribution rates.
responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
stakeholders: Participants and employers in the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new approach to funding administrative expenses directly from the system's funds rather than through separate employer fees, streamlining funding and potentially reducing administrative burdens.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's impact on child poverty is indirect and minimal, primarily affecting pension system funding mechanisms.

Title: Residential Real Property - Landlord and Tenant - Notice of Landlord Entry
Synopsis: Requiring a landlord to provide a tenant with certain written notice in a certain manner at least 24 hours in advance of when the landlord intends to enter a leased premises, except in the event of a certain emergency; and authorizing the court to issue a certain injunction or assess certain damages under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: This bill requires landlords of residential properties in Maryland to give tenants written notice before entering the leased premises, except in emergencies, and specifies the manner and timing of such notices.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Tenants and landlords of residential properties in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a structured approach to tenant notification, including electronic delivery options, which is a modern approach to landlord-tenant communication.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty but improves tenant rights and housing stability.

Title: Prince George's County - Federal Bureau of Investigation Headquarters - Mandated Appropriation
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to include $200,000,000 in the annual operating or capital budget bill for site redevelopment and transportation infrastructure improvements if the U.S. General Services Administration applies to Prince George's County or the State for a permit associated with the relocation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation Headquarters to Prince George's County.
bill_summary: The bill mandates that the Maryland governor include at least $200 million in the annual budget for site redevelopment and transportation infrastructure improvements if the U.S. General Services Administration relocates the FBI headquarters to Prince George's County.
responsible_party: Maryland State Government, specifically the Governor's Office and the Department of Finance and Procurement
stakeholders: Residents and workers in Prince George's County, Maryland, and federal agencies involved in the FBI headquarters relocation
innovative_summary: The bill employs a conditional funding approach tied to a federal agency relocation, which is a strategic government planning and budgeting approach.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on infrastructure and site redevelopment.

Title: Local Government - Local Personnel - Leave With Pay
Synopsis: Establishing that governmental units may provide disaster service leave with pay to certain employees; establishing that an employee of a governmental unit of a county or a municipality in the State may be entitled to disaster service leave with pay under certain circumstances; authorizing certain governmental units to waive certain requirements for disaster service leave; and authorizing a governmental unit of a county or a municipality to provide leave with pay under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill allows local government units in Maryland to provide disaster service leave with pay to employees who volunteer during disasters, and also to provide paid leave for jury service, union activities, military service, court appearances, emergency removal, and other necessary reasons.
responsible_party: Local government units in Maryland
stakeholders: Employees of counties and municipalities, disaster response volunteers, military personnel, and citizens affected by disasters
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a structured approach for local governments to provide paid leave for disaster volunteers and other emergency-related activities, enhancing disaster response and employee support.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program could indirectly support child poverty reduction by enabling better disaster response and employee stability, but it is not directly targeted at child poverty.

Title: Health Insurance - Individual Market Stabilization - Establishment of the State-Based Health Insurance Subsidies Program
Synopsis: Establishing the State-Based Health Insurance Subsidies Program to provide subsidies to individuals in the State to mitigate the impact of a reduction in certain federal advance premium tax credits for calendar years 2026 through 2028; and requiring the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to implement the Program under certain circumstances.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the State–Based Health Insurance Subsidies Program to provide subsidies to individuals in Maryland to offset the impact of potential reductions in federal premium tax credits, and creates a dedicated fund to support various health insurance programs.
responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
stakeholders: Individuals purchasing health insurance in Maryland, especially those affected by federal tax credit reductions
innovative_summary: The program employs a targeted subsidy approach to stabilize the individual health insurance market in response to federal policy changes, utilizing a dedicated fund and regulatory oversight.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a moderate potential to reduce child poverty by making health insurance more affordable for families.

Title: Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access - Plan to Implement Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring the Behavioral Health Advisory Council and the Commission on Behavioral Health Care Treatment and Access, through its workgroup, to implement Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment requirements; requiring the workgroup to provide recommendations to implement recommendations in a certain Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services State Health Official letter; and requiring the Maryland Department of Health to report its findings and recommendations to the General Assembly by January 1, 2026.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to convene a workgroup to develop a plan for implementing Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSDT) requirements for children's behavioral health. It involves creating recommendations for screening, assessment, community-based services, and addressing urgent needs, with a report due by January 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Children with behavioral health issues, their families, healthcare providers, and advocates in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program employs a collaborative approach involving multiple stakeholders to develop a comprehensive plan for implementing EPSDT requirements, including the use of diagnostic tools like DC:0–5 and community-based services.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to directly impact child poverty by improving access to behavioral health services for children, which can lead to better health and social outcomes.

Title: Housing Authorities - Tax-Exempt Status - Modifications
Synopsis: Exempting certain real property owned by certain nonprofit entities created by public housing authorities from State and local property taxation; directing certain nonprofit entities created by public housing authorities to make payment in lieu of taxes that may be set by mutual agreement with a political subdivision; and applying the Act to all taxable years beginning after June 30, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill modifies the tax-exempt status of property owned by public housing authorities and certain nonprofit entities created by them, allowing these entities to be exempt from state and local taxes and to make payments in lieu of taxes through mutual agreements.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
stakeholders: Public housing authorities, nonprofit housing entities, and residents of affordable housing in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new approach for tax exemptions and payments in lieu of taxes for public housing-related entities, streamlining their tax status and agreements.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has the potential to support affordable housing development, which can help reduce child poverty by increasing access to stable housing.

Title: Maryland Medical Assistance Program and Health Insurance - Coverage for Anesthesia - Prohibiting Time Limitations
Synopsis: Requiring, beginning January 1, 2026, the Maryland Medical Assistance Program, managed care organizations, and certain insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations, if providing coverage for the delivery of anesthesia for a procedure for which a licensed medical professional issues an order, to provide the coverage for the duration of the procedure; prohibiting the establishment, implementation, or enforcement of policies or practices  that place time limitations on the delivery of anesthesia; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program and certain health insurance providers to cover the full duration of anesthesia for procedures, without imposing time limits, starting from January 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Medical Assistance Program and insurance providers (managed care organizations, insurers, nonprofit health plans, and health maintenance organizations)
stakeholders: Patients receiving anesthesia during medical procedures in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill enforces a policy to eliminate arbitrary time limits on anesthesia coverage, ensuring comprehensive care during procedures, which is a regulatory change rather than a technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's focus on healthcare coverage for anesthesia does not directly impact child poverty.

Title: Health Insurance - Step Therapy or Fail-First Protocols - Drugs to Treat Associated Conditions of Advanced Metastatic Cancer
Synopsis: Prohibiting certain insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and health maintenance organizations from imposing a step therapy or fail-first protocol for certain prescription drugs prescribed by a treating physician to treat a symptom of or side effect from the treatment of stage four metastatic cancer and use of the prescription drug is consistent with best practices for treatment of the condition.
bill_summary: This bill prohibits certain health insurers and plans from imposing step therapy or fail-first protocols on prescription drugs used to treat symptoms or side effects of advanced metastatic cancer, under specific circumstances.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health or relevant health insurance regulatory agency
stakeholders: Patients with advanced metastatic cancer, healthcare providers, insurers, and health plans in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a targeted exemption to existing step therapy protocols for a specific, serious medical condition, ensuring timely access to necessary medications.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, as it primarily addresses adult cancer treatment protocols.

Title: Montgomery County - Alcoholic Beverages - Beauty Salon and Barbershop License MC 3-25
Synopsis: Expanding eligibility for a certain beauty salon license in Montgomery County to include a holder of a certain barbershop permit; authorizing a holder of the license to provide up to 1.7 ounces of liquor for on-premises consumption in addition to beer and wine; and authorizing the holder to provide not more than 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.7 ounces of liquor for on-premises consumption by a beauty salon or barbershop customer; and requiring an annual license fee of $100.
bill_summary: The bill expands the eligibility for a beauty salon license in Montgomery County to include holders of barbershop permits, allowing them to provide a limited amount of liquor, beer, and wine for on-premises consumption, and makes related adjustments to licensing rules.
responsible_party: Montgomery County Department of Permitting Services
stakeholders: Beauty salons, barbershops, customers in Montgomery County
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new licensing category that allows beauty salons and barbershops to serve alcohol, integrating alcohol service into existing beauty and grooming businesses.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty, primarily affecting business licensing and alcohol service regulations.

Title: Insurance - Automobile Insurance - Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund and Affordability Study
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund to calculate and report its risk based capital level in accordance with certain provisions of insurance law and maintain total adjusted capital in a certain amount; establishing that certain provisions of insurance law regarding prior approval rate making apply to the Fund during a certain time period and under certain circumstances; requiring the Maryland Insurance Administration to establish a workgroup to study automobile insurance affordability; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund to calculate and report its risk-based capital levels, maintain certain capital thresholds, and submit plans if capital levels fall below specified thresholds. It also establishes a workgroup to study automobile insurance affordability and transparency, and authorizes the Fund to certify a financial assessment amount.
responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Administration and Maryland Automobile Insurance Fund
stakeholders: Automobile insurance consumers, insurers, and stakeholders in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive approach combining financial regulation, transparency initiatives, and a dedicated study workgroup to address automobile insurance affordability and financial stability.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty but may indirectly benefit low-income families through improved insurance affordability and stability.

Title: Public Health - Health Equity Dashboard
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Department of Health, in collaboration with the Commission on Health Equity, to develop a clear and easy-to-understand graphic data dashboard that includes age-adjusted health disparity data disaggregated by race, ethnicity, and gender; and requiring the Department to update the data dashboard on a quarterly basis, as determined by data availability.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health, in collaboration with the Commission on Health Equity, to develop and maintain a health equity data dashboard that displays various health disparities data disaggregated by race, ethnicity, and gender, and to update it regularly.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health in collaboration with the Commission on Health Equity
stakeholders: Public health officials, policymakers, and communities affected by health disparities in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a health data dashboard as a tool for visualizing health disparities, which is a modern approach to health equity and data transparency.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has the potential to improve health equity, which can indirectly impact child poverty by addressing disparities affecting children.

Title: Maryland Department of Health - AHEAD Model Implementation - Electronic Health Care Transactions and Population Health Improvement Fund
Synopsis: Clarifying that electronic health care transactions information may be used to support the participation of the State in the States Advancing All-Payer Health Equity Approaches and Development (AHEAD) Model and any successor models; establishing the Population Health Improvement Fund to support the statewide population health targets under the AHEAD Model and any successor models; authorizing the Health Services Cost Review Commission to assess a uniform, broad-based, and reasonable amount in hospital rates to be credited to the Fund; etc.
bill_summary: This bill clarifies the use of electronic health care transaction data to support Maryland's participation in the AHEAD Model, establishes a Population Health Improvement Fund to invest in population health initiatives, and sets up reporting and funding mechanisms to support health equity and population health targets.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Health Services Cost Review Commission
stakeholders: Public health populations, healthcare providers, and policymakers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs innovative approaches by integrating electronic health data for health equity initiatives and establishing a dedicated fund for population health improvements aligned with federal models.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by improving health outcomes and reducing disparities, which can contribute to economic stability for vulnerable populations.

Title: Allegany County - Alcoholic Beverages - Minimum Age for Employment of Underage Individuals
Synopsis: Altering the minimum age for employment in Allegany County for alcoholic beverages license holders that do not derive more than half of their revenues from the sale of food from 16 years of age to 18 years of age.
bill_summary: The bill amends the laws in Allegany County to change the minimum age for employment at alcoholic beverage license holders, allowing individuals aged 18 to 21 to be employed, with certain conditions based on revenue sources.
responsible_party: Allegany County government or licensing authority
stakeholders: Underage individuals seeking employment, alcoholic beverage license holders, local economy in Allegany County
innovative_summary: The bill primarily changes employment age restrictions for alcohol license holders in Allegany County, which is a regulatory adjustment rather than an innovative program.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty as it mainly adjusts employment age regulations for a specific county.

Title: Public Utilities - Solar Energy Generating Systems - Systems Located on or Over Water Retention Ponds, Quarries, or Brownfields
Synopsis: Providing that solar energy generating systems located on or over certain water retention ponds or quarries are eligible for the Small Solar Energy Generating System Incentive Program; and authorizing the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or the governing body of a county or municipal corporation to grant by law, a certain property tax credit against the county or municipal corporation property tax imposed on certain nonresidential solar energy generating systems.
bill_summary: The bill expands the eligibility for the Small Solar Energy Generating System Incentive Program to include floating solar systems on water retention ponds, quarries, or brownfields, and allows local governments to grant property tax credits for such systems. It also clarifies that certain nonresidential solar systems on brownfields, water retention ponds, or quarries are exempt from property tax.
responsible_party: Maryland Public Utilities Commission and local governments (Baltimore City and counties)
stakeholders: Nonresidential solar energy system owners, local governments, and communities near brownfields, water retention ponds, or quarries
innovative_summary: The bill introduces the inclusion of floating solar systems on water retention ponds, quarries, and brownfields into existing solar incentive programs and property tax credits, employing a new approach to utilizing underused land and water areas for solar energy.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, primarily through promoting renewable energy projects that may benefit local communities.

Title: Public Safety - State Clearinghouse for Missing Persons
Synopsis: Renaming and transferring the State Clearinghouse for Missing Children to be the State Clearinghouse for Missing Persons; requiring the Department of State Police to study the Department's capacity to report about persons who have disappeared from, or thought to be located in Maryland, to the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System; and requiring the Department to submit its findings to the Governor and the General Assembly by December 1, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill renames the State Clearinghouse for Missing Children to the State Clearinghouse for Missing Persons, transfers its responsibilities to the Department of State Police, and requires the department to report on its capacity to share missing persons data with the national system by December 1, 2025.
responsible_party: Department of State Police
stakeholders: Missing persons, law enforcement agencies, families of missing persons
innovative_summary: The bill involves updating and expanding the data sharing system for missing persons, including a study on reporting capacity, which employs data integration and inter-agency coordination approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on missing persons data systems.

Title: Child Care Scholarship Program - Youth Transitioning From Foster Placement to Successful Adulthood Program - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Youth Transitioning From Foster Placement to Successful Adulthood Program in the Child Care Scholarship Program to remove certain application barriers for parenting foster youth and increase eligibility access to the Child Care Scholarship Program;
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Youth Transitioning From Foster Placement to Successful Adulthood Pilot Program within the Child Care Scholarship Program to assist foster youth in accessing child care subsidies and removing application barriers.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education
stakeholders: Foster youth aged 16 to 21 and their children in Maryland
innovative_summary: The program employs a targeted approach to remove barriers for foster youth accessing child care subsidies and integrates a pilot program to support youth transitioning from foster care.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to directly impact child poverty by increasing access to child care subsidies for foster youth and their children.

Title: Office of Child Care Advisory Council - Membership - Alterations
Synopsis: Increasing the maximum number of members of the Office of Child Care Advisory Council from 30 to 31; and adding a representative of the Maryland Association of Public Library Administrators to the membership of the Council.
bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum number of members on the Maryland Office of Child Care Advisory Council from 30 to 31, adds a representative from the Maryland Association of Public Library Administrators to the Council, and makes related adjustments to the Council's membership composition.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of Child Care
stakeholders: Child care providers, public libraries, government agencies, and children in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill primarily modifies the membership structure of an existing advisory council, with no new programs or innovative approaches introduced.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty as it mainly concerns advisory council membership.

Title: Correctional Services - Geriatric and Medical Parole
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Parole Commission to consider the age of an incarcerated individual when determining whether to grant parole; altering how the Commission evaluates a request for medical parole; requiring the Commission to develop procedures for assessing parole requests by certain incarcerated individuals; repealing the authorization for the Governor to disapprove of a decision by the Commission to grant medical parole; requiring the Commission to conduct a certain risk assessment at a certain time; etc.
bill_summary: This bill reforms Maryland's medical and geriatric parole laws, including removing gubernatorial approval for certain medical parole decisions, establishing procedures for evaluating parole requests, and creating programs for elderly and medically incapacitated inmates to be considered for parole.
responsible_party: Maryland Parole Commission and Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals, especially elderly and medically incapacitated inmates, victims, and the public
innovative_summary: The bill introduces new procedures for medical and geriatric parole, including risk assessments and specific criteria for eligibility, and emphasizes data collection and reporting, employing a more structured and data-driven approach to parole decisions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has limited direct impact on child poverty, focusing mainly on parole procedures for incarcerated individuals.

Title: Dorchester County - Well and On-Site Sewage Disposal Activities - Privatization Program
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of the Environment, at the request of the Dorchester County government and the local health department or county agency in Dorchester County that has received a well or on-site sewage disposal system delegation of authority by the Department, to establish a privatization program for the performance of activities associated with the well or on-site sewage disposal system delegation of authority in Dorchester County.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Department of the Environment to establish a privatization program in Dorchester County for the performance of activities related to well and on-site sewage disposal systems, at the request of the county government and a delegated approval authority.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Residents and businesses in Dorchester County requiring well and sewage disposal services
innovative_summary: The program introduces a privatization approach for environmental health activities, including oversight, compliance audits, and record transfer, which is a relatively new approach in government service delivery.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to improve access and quality of sewage disposal services, which can indirectly impact child health and well-being.

Title: Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring - Report Alterations and Data Collection
Synopsis: Requiring the Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring to study and make recommendations to the General Assembly regarding certain policies, practices, and responses when a person violates a condition of home detention monitoring; and requiring the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to collect and report to the Workgroup certain data on or before September 1 each year.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a Workgroup on Home Detention Monitoring to study policies, practices, and responses related to violations of home detention conditions, and requires the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services to collect and report relevant data.
responsible_party: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
stakeholders: Individuals on home detention, law enforcement, judicial system, correctional agencies, and monitoring agencies in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a collaborative, data-driven approach to improve home detention monitoring policies and responses, involving multiple stakeholders and annual reporting.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to impact child poverty by improving monitoring and responses, which could lead to more effective detention practices and support for affected families.

Title: Unemployment Insurance - Child Support Arrearage to Work Pilot Program - Established
Synopsis: Establishing a Child Support Arrearage to Work Pilot Program within the Department of Labor to connect individuals who are unemployed and in arrears under a child support order with employment opportunities in the State; and requiring the Department to report on or before July 1, 2026, on the Department's findings and any recommendations related to the continuation of the Program.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Child Support Arrearage to Work Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of Labor. The program aims to connect unemployed individuals who are in arrears on child support with employment opportunities in Maryland, including government jobs. The Department, in collaboration with other agencies, will implement and oversee the program, and report on its findings by July 1, 2026.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor, in consultation with the Department of Human Services and the Department of Budget and Management
stakeholders: Unemployed individuals in arrears on child support, child support enforcement agencies, and the Maryland workforce
innovative_summary: The program employs a targeted approach to address child support arrearages by directly connecting delinquent payers with employment opportunities, including government jobs, leveraging inter-agency collaboration.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has potential to reduce child poverty by helping parents in arrears find employment and meet child support obligations.

Title: Public Health - Buprenorphine - Training Grant Program and Workgroup
Synopsis: Establishing the Buprenorphine Training Grant Program to assist counties with offsetting the cost of training paramedics to administer buprenorphine; including the Program as an authorized use of funding from the Opioid Restitution Fund; requiring the Governor to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation of at least $50,000 from the Opioid Restitution Fund for the Program; and requiring the Maryland Office of Overdose Response to convene a workgroup to study access to buprenorphine in the State.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Buprenorphine Training Grant Program to help counties fund training paramedics to administer buprenorphine, and creates a workgroup to study access to buprenorphine in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Office of Overdose Response
stakeholders: Paramedics, counties, individuals with opioid use disorder, healthcare providers, and the general public in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill employs a comprehensive approach by combining funding for paramedic training with a dedicated workgroup to analyze and improve access to buprenorphine, integrating data collection and strategic planning.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a moderate potential to impact child poverty by improving access to opioid treatment and reducing overdose deaths, which can stabilize families and communities.

Title: Baltimore County - Alcoholic Beverages - Change of Location
Synopsis: Establishing an additional circumstance under which the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County may approve a change of location for a certain alcoholic beverages license; and providing that the Board may approve a certain change if the license was originally issued within the same election district and has been at the same location for a least 10 years.
bill_summary: The bill amends Baltimore County's rules for changing the location of alcoholic beverages licenses, adding a new circumstance under which a license location change can be approved, specifically if the license has been at the same location for at least 10 years.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Board of License Commissioners
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders and businesses in Baltimore County
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new eligibility criterion for license location changes based on the duration at the current location, which is a straightforward regulatory change without employing new technologies or approaches.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill has minimal direct impact on child poverty as it mainly changes licensing rules for alcohol sales.

Title: Public Health - Maryland Interested Parties Advisory Group - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Interested Parties Advisory Group to ensure adequate access to applicable home- and community-based services in the State; requiring the Maryland Department of Health to provide certain support to the Advisory Group; and requiring by September 1 each year beginning in 2026, the Advisory Group to report its activities and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the Maryland Interested Parties Advisory Group to ensure access to home- and community-based services and a qualified direct care workforce, and to advise on Medicaid payment rates and workforce conditions.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Direct care workers, consumers of Medicaid home- and community-based services, provider organizations, and the general public in Maryland.
innovative_summary: The program employs a comprehensive advisory group with diverse stakeholders, data-driven reporting, and public engagement strategies to improve Medicaid services and workforce conditions.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to impact child poverty by improving access and quality of home- and community-based services, which can support families and children in need.

Title: Maryland Collaborative to Improve Children's Oral Health Through School-Based Programs - Establishment
Synopsis: Establishing the Maryland Collaborative to Improve Children's Oral Health Through School-Based Programs to study and make recommendations on ways to improve school-based dental programs; and requiring the Collaborative to submit an interim report by December 1, 2025, and a final report on its findings and recommendations by October 1, 2026.
bill_summary: This bill establishes a program to improve children's oral health in Maryland through school-based dental services, including licensing provisions for dental hygienists to work under supervision in schools, and creates a Maryland Collaborative to study and recommend improvements to these programs.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
stakeholders: Children in Maryland, especially those in underserved communities, school health programs, dental providers, and families
innovative_summary: The bill employs a collaborative approach to study and improve school-based dental programs, including expanding roles for dental hygienists and integrating services into schools, which is a relatively innovative approach to public health intervention.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program has a high potential to reduce child poverty by improving access to dental care, which can lead to better health and educational outcomes for children in underserved communities.

Title: State Public Transit Service and Stations - Exclusion for Assault and Bodily Injury
Synopsis: Providing that a person alleged by a public transit operator to have committed an assault or other intentional act causing bodily injury may be prohibited from using a State public transit service or entering a State public transit service station; requiring the Maryland Transit Administration to create a rider code of conduct and implement a comprehensive internal safety program to strengthen protection for operators and passengers; etc.
bill_summary: The bill allows individuals accused of assault or causing bodily injury on public transit or at transit stations to continue using transit services and entering stations, under certain conditions and an appeals process. It also requires the Maryland Transit Administration to create a rider code of conduct and implement a safety program to protect operators and passengers.
responsible_party: Maryland Transit Administration
stakeholders: Public transit riders, operators, and passengers in Maryland
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a new approach to transit safety by allowing individuals accused of assault to continue using transit services under specific conditions, and by establishing a comprehensive safety and conduct program.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The program's direct impact on child poverty is likely minimal, as it mainly focuses on transit safety and conduct policies.

Title: Baltimore County - Alcoholic Beverages - Waiting Period After License Denial
Synopsis: Establishing in Baltimore County certain waiting periods for the application for or issuance of an alcoholic beverages license at a specific location if an application for a license at that location has been previously denied.
bill_summary: This bill establishes waiting periods in Baltimore County for applying for or receiving an alcoholic beverages license if an application for that location has previously been denied. Specifically, it prohibits new applications for 1 year after a first denial and for 2 years after a second denial at the same location.
responsible_party: Baltimore County Alcoholic Beverages Licensing Board
stakeholders: Alcohol license applicants, Baltimore County residents, local businesses
innovative_summary: The bill introduces a structured waiting period system for license applications following denials, which is a regulatory approach rather than a technological innovation.
child_poverty_direct_summary: The bill's impact on child poverty is likely minimal as it mainly affects licensing procedures for alcohol sales.

Title: Maryland Behavioral Health Crisis Response System – Integration of 9–8–8 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline Network and Outcome Evaluations
